ul.li: Learn how to compute the correlation (r).
Practice interpreting the value of the correlation.
See an example of how including an outlier can increase the correlation.

body.p: Recall the following example: The average gestation period, or time of pregnancy, of an animal is closely related to its longevity—the length of its lifespan. Data on the average gestation period and longevity (in captivity) of 40 different species of animals have been recorded.

alternative.title: R Instructions
alternative.p: To open R with the dataset preloaded, right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and double-click it to open it in R.
The data have been loaded into the data frame a. Enter the command a to see the data. The variables in a are animal, gestation, and longevity.

ul.li: animal: the name of the animal species
gestation: the average gestation period of the species, in days
longevity: the average longevity of the species, in years

alternative.p: Notice that the correlation between gestation and longevity has changed.

alternative.title: StatCrunch Instructions
alternative.p: To open the file (animals.xls) in StatCrunch you must first right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Next click here to open StatCrunch in a separate window and login using your username and password.

ul.li: Click on the link "Open StatCrunch" at the top of the My StatCrunch page.
To open the data set, click on the Data button in the top row and select Load → From file → on my computer.
Under File, press the Browse button and select the data set you downloaded.
Scroll to the bottom of the page and click on "Load File."

alternative.p: Our dataset contains the following variables:
animal: the name of the animal species.
gestation: the average gestation period of the species, in days.
longevity: the average longevity of the species, in years.

alternative.title: Minitab Instructions
alternative.p: To open Minitab with the data in the worksheet, right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and double-click it to open it in Minitab. Note: a dialog box will likely appear that says "A copy of the content of this file will be added to the current project"—just click OK.
Our dataset contains the following variables:
animal: the name of the animal species.
gestation: the average gestation period of the species, in days.
longevity: the average longevity of the species, in years.

alternative.title: Excel 2013 and 2016 Instructions
alternative.p: To open the dataset, click here to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and double-click it to open it in Excel. When Excel opens you may have to enable editing.
Our dataset contains the following variables:
animal: the name of the animal species.
gestation: the average gestation period of the species, in days.
longevity: the average longevity of the species, in years.

alternative.title: TI Instructions
alternative.p: To open a group of lists with the data for the animals loaded, right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and send it to your calculator. For instructions on how to connect your calculator to your computer and transfer a file, click here.
On the TI calculator, the dataset is displayed in lists L1-L2:

ul.li: L1: Gestation—the average gestation period of the species, in days.
L2: Longevity—the average longevity of the species, in years.

body.p: Remember that the correlation is only an appropriate measure of the linear relationship between two quantitative variables. First produce a scatterplot to verify that gestation and longevity are nearly linear in their relationship.

alternative.title: R Instructions
alternative.p: To do this in R, copy the entire command below:
alternative.code: plot(a$longevity,a$gestation,xlab="Average Longevity of Species (years)", ylab="Average Gestation Period of Species (days)")

alternative.title: StatCrunch Instructions
alternative.p: Here's a reminder of how to do this in StatCrunch:

ul.li: Choose Graph → Scatter Plot
For the X column select longevity and for the Y column select gestation.
Press Compute!

alternative.title: Minitab Instructions
alternative.p: Here's a reminder of how to do this in Minitab:

ul.li: Choose Graph → Scatterplot → Simple.
Enter the response variable (Y) and the explanatory variable (X).
Click "OK."

alternative.title: Excel 2007 Instructions
alternative.p: Here's a reminder of how to do this in Excel:

ul.li: Select all of the data in columns B and C, and then choose Scatter in the Charts group on the Insert tab (click on the picture of a scatterplot).
Choose the first scatterplot option (Scatter with only Markers).

alternative.title: TI Instructions

ul.li: Either clear any equations you may have in your calculator by choosing Y=/CLEAR, or else toggle them off by choosing Y= and then pressing the left arrow until = is selected and pressing ENTER.
Choose STAT PLOT (2ND/Y=).
Choose 4:PlotsOff.
Press ENTER.
You should see:
Again, choose STAT PLOT (2ND/Y=).
Choose 1:Plot1…Off.
Turn the plot ON by using arrows to highlight the word ON, then press ENTER.
Choose the Type: the first graph is a scatterplot.
Choose L1 (2ND/1) for Xlist.
Choose L2 (2ND/2) for Ylist.
Choose the Mark you prefer.
You should see
To view the scatterplot, choose ZOOM/9: ZoomStat.

alternative.p: Note: If you prefer to set the viewing window yourself, choose WINDOW and set the values yourself for Xmin, Xmax, Xscl, Ymin, Ymax, Yscl. If the x-axis/y-axis show as a dark line, you can make Xscl/Yscl larger.

body.p: Observe that the relationship between gestation period and longevity is linear and positive. Now we will compute the correlation between gestation period and longevity.

alternative.title: R Instructions
alternative.p: To do that in R, copy the command:

Now return to the scatterplot that you created earlier. Notice that there is an outlier in both longevity (40 years) and gestation (645 days). Note: This outlier corresponds to the longevity and gestation period of the elephant.

alternative.title: StatCrunch Instructions
alternative.p: To do that in StatCrunch:

ul.li: Choose Stat → Summary Stats → Correlation.
Select the columns longevity and gestation by pressing (Shift+click) or (Ctrl+click).
Press Compute!

alternative.title: Minitab Instructions
alternative.p: To do that in Minitab:

ul.li: Choose Stat → Basic Statistics → Correlation. This will bring up the Correlation dialog box.
To fill in the "Variables": double-click on the two relevant variables in the left panel (gestation and longevity)
Uncheck "Display p-values." We won't need that right now.
Click "OK."

alternative.title: Excel 2007 Instructions
alternative.p: To do that in Excel:

ul.li: Click in a cell outside of the first three columns of data.
Type =correl(B2:B41,C2:C41)

IMPORTANT: Instead of typing the B2:B41, C2:C41 inside of the parentheses, it is better to highlight the relevant cells with your mouse after typing =min( (by holding a left click as you highlight the cells).

alternative.title: TI Instructions
alternative.p: Choose STAT/CALC/8:LinReg(a+bx).
You'll see: LinReg(a + bx)
Choose the Xlist and Ylist. Since the gestation data is in L1 and the longevity data is in L2, enter 2nd/1 after Xlist. Enter 2nd/2 after Ylist. Leave FreqList and Store RegEQ blank.
Highlight Calculate and press ENTER
Once you have LinReg(a+bx) L1,L2 then press ENTER
Note: If you don’t enter any lists, then L1,L2 is the default.
You should now see:

ul.li: LinReg
y=a+bx
a=
b=
r=

alternative.p: If you don’t see r2 and r, you need to turn DiagnosticOn: Choose CATALOG (2ND/0) and then arrow down to choose DiagnosticOn (list is alphabetical). Hit ENTER and the screen will display Done. You will only have to do this once unless the TI memory gets reset.

body.p: Now return to the scatterplot that you created earlier. Notice that there is an outlier in both longevity (40 years) and gestation (645 days). Note: This outlier corresponds to the longevity and gestation period of the elephant.
What do you think will happen to the correlation if we remove this outlier?

alternative.title: R Instructions
alternative.p: To do this in R, copy the following command:
Notice that the correlation between gestation and longevity has changed.

alternative.title: StatCrunch Instructions
alternative.p: To do that in StatCrunch:

li.p: Scroll down to row 15 of the data. You will see that this contains the values of the variables for the elephant.
Click on the row header “15” to select the entire row of data.
In response to “Delete 1 selected rows?” press Compute!

alternative.p: You will see that the values for the elephant have been removed from the data.
Recompute the correlation between gestation and longevity.

alternative.title: Minitab Instructions
alternative.p: To do this in Minitab:

ul.li: Scroll down to row 15 of the data. You will see that this contains the values of the variables for the elephant.
Click on the row header "15" to select the entire row of data.
Choose Edit → Delete Cells.

alternative.p: You will see that the values of the variables for the elephant have been removed from the data. Recompute the correlation between gestation and longevity.

alternative.title: Excel 2007 Instructions
alternative.p: To do this in Excel:

ul.li: Scroll down to row 16 of the data. You will see that this contains the values of the variables for the elephant.
Click on the row header 16 to select the entire row of data.
Right-click and choose Delete from the pop-up menu to delete the row.

alternative.p: You will see that the values of the variables for the elephant have been removed from the data. Notice also that the correlation between gestation and longevity has changed.

alternative.title: TI Instructions
alternative.p: Delete 645 from the gestation list (L1) and 40 from the longevity list (L2). These should be L1(15) and L2(15).

ul.li: Choose STAT/EDIT/1:Edit...
Arrow down in L1 until you've highlighted 645.
Press DEL.
Use the right arrow to highlight 40 in L2.
Press DEL.

alternative.p: You will see that the values of the variables for this outlier have been removed from the data.
Recalculate the correlation:

ul.li: Choose STAT/CALC/8:LinReg(a+bx).

Choose the Xlist and Ylist. Since the gestation data is in L1 and the longevity data is in L2, enter 2nd/1 after Xlist. Enter 2nd/2 after Ylist. Leave FreqList and Store RegEQ blank. Highlight Calculate and press ENTER
Once you have LinReg(a+bx) L1,L2, press ENTER

body.p: In the last activity, we saw an example where there was a positive linear relationship between the two variables, and including the outlier just "strengthened" it. Consider the hypothetical data displayed by the following scatterplot:
In this case, the low outlier gives an "illusion" of a positive linear relationship, whereas in reality, there is no linear relationship between X and Y.
